children.subject: @ student response: Thanks for your input! Any particular reason why you would argue that's the case?

As repeated numerous times on this piazza, different preparation is useful for different cs189 professors. I took 1cs89 with Shewchuck in sp19 with Stat 140 (equivalent of Stat134)  and CS70 as part of my background, and felt perfectly prepared. This may not be the case for the fall professors. 

I can say for sure that Stat135 is not necessary for either version. It's a great class, that covers some statistical theory ignored by many ML courses, but it covers what you might call "statistics" - linear regression, hypothesis testing - while most ML courses require knowledge of probability -  e.g. random variables, distributions, and their properties like expectation and variance. 

If you've taken stat135 before, you might have some cool background knowledge on regression in CS189, but its definitely not enough to deem stat135 a necessary pre-req. That being said,  its  a cool class if you've got space in your schedule for some inference!c

^ Adding to that, I really advise you to take 126 it's a great class and you learn a lot of really cool stuff that can be applied almost anywhere. Yes the class is hard but it's also curved really nicely!

A lot of topics in 189 touch on things you learn in 135. I felt that 134 prepared me well for the probability part of 189 and 135 further helped in preparing for different topics such as MLE, for example.

Of course 126 would be much better as it essentially combines the relevant parts of 134 and 135 that you will need for 189

If you end up taking 189 with anyone apart from Shewchuck, I would recommend taking 126/127 before hand. I took 189 this semester with Listengarten/Yu and I felt much more prepared taking it after taking both, and I felt like I was able to understand the probability and optimization aspects of the classes much better than others who haven't taken either of those two classes. For probability in particular, you may be able to get away with 134 if they cover multivariate gaussians in depth, I haven't taken that class so I'm not super familiar with what they cover.

history.content: Hi I was wondering if Stat 134, Stat 135, or EECS 126 would provide the best preparation in terms of probability math background before taking CS 189? In terms of both content covered and rigor of each of the courses. Thanks!
history.subject: Probability Preparation for CS 189
